  • Element
com.nitnelave.xmlparser

Annotation Type XMLNode


  • @Documented
@Retention(value=RUNTIME)
@Target(value=TYPE)
public @interface XMLNode

    Annotation to describe an XML node structure. For the properties, see XMLProperties.

    There are 3 special types of nodes:
    • Root nodes, defined by parentNode = RootNode.class. Root nodes cannot have parents, and will raise an exception if read as an inner node.
    • Generic child nodes, defined by parentNode = None.class. These can have parents of any type.
    • Default node, defined by parentNode = DefaultNode.class. It must be unique. If an unknown XML tag is recognized, a default node is created. Its name attribute will be ignored, but if the class provides a setName(String name) method, it will be called with the name of the tag. The default node can have properties, but they cannot be required.
    Otherwise, a node can only be parsed as a direct child of its parentNode, or it will raise an exception.

    Upon reading the opening tag, the handleBegin(MyNode n) will be called for every applicable registered listener. At this point, the node only has information about its properties.

    Upon reading the closing tag, the handle(MyNode n) will be called for every applicable registered listener. At this point, the node has all information available: properties, content, and sub-nodes.

    If a node is missing a property marked required, any corresponding XML tag missing the property will raise an exception upon parsing.

    Constructors

    • The XML nodes will be created with the empty constructor. Make sure to provide a meaningful one.
    • The classes for the node content and the properties must have a constructor taking a String as unique parameter. For a simple number, use Integer.class.
    Author:
    nitnelave
    See Also:
    XMLParser, XMLProperty, XMLProperties, XMLStructureException

    • Required Element Summary

      Required Elements 
      Modifier and Type Required Element and Description
      java.lang.String name
      The name of the XML tag to recognize, and the name of the parent method to set the child.
      java.lang.Class<?> parentNode
      The class of the parent node in the XML structure.

    • Optional Element Summary

      Optional Elements 
      Modifier and Type Optional Element and Description
      java.lang.Class<?> contentType
      The class of the (optional) content.
      boolean single
      The arity of the node.

    • Element Detail

      • name

        public abstract java.lang.String name
        The name of the XML tag to recognize, and the name of the parent method to set the child. As xml is case insensitive, it is recommended to type this field in CamelCase.
        I.e. if the field is Node, then the method addNode(Node n) of the parent node will be called if found.

        NB: The prefix of the method can be changed with the single field.

        Returns:
        The name of the XML tag

      • parentNode

        public abstract java.lang.Class<?> parentNode
        The class of the parent node in the XML structure.
        If the class is RootNode, then the node is marked as root, and likewise for DefaultNode.
        Returns:
        The parent node's class

      • contentType

        public abstract java.lang.Class<?> contentType
        The class of the (optional) content.
        This defines what object will be constructed from the content inside the XML tag. If the contentType is not None, then the class must define a method setContent(String s).
        Returns:
        The content class.
        Default:
        com.nitnelave.xmlparser.None.class

      • single

        public abstract boolean single
        The arity of the node.
        Determines the name of the method called when adding the node to its parent node.
        If it is false (default), the name of the method is "add" + name;
        if true, it is "set" + name;
        Returns:
        True if it is a single node.
        Default:
        false
